title: CSS Display Property
subject: CSS
theory:

examples.output: Links appearing side-by-side but with specific dimensions.
examples.explanation: Useful for navigation menus where you want clickable areas to be specific sizes.

common_mistakes.correction: `width`, `height`, `margin-top`, `margin-bottom` do NOT work on `display: inline` elements.
common_mistakes.example: Change to display: inline-block or block.

interview_questions.question: What is the difference between `display: none` and `visibility: hidden`?
interview_questions.answer: `display: none` removes the element from the document flow (no space). `visibility: hidden` hides it but occupies the same space.

interview_questions.question: When would you use `inline-block`?
interview_questions.answer: When you want elements side-by-side (like text) but need to control their dimensions (padding/margin/width).

practice_problems.problem: Hide an element with id='secret' so it takes no space.

real_world_use_cases.description: On mobile, a menu might be `display: none` until a hamburger button is clicked (Javascript toggles it to `display: block`).

exam_notes: Every HTML element has a default display value (usually block or inline).
Flex and Grid are also values of the display property.
summary: Understanding `display` is the key to understanding how elements position themselves on the page.
